Enroute - Shanghai, to Peiping
Jan. 18,
1936.
Dear Slim and Anne:
autographed copy of "North
it is one
wont to walt Debo a lila at and he and mat ay and
progressing satisfactorily.
Macao 1s like a bit of old Europe picked
up and placed in the Orient.
The houses are all neat stucco or brick
Chinese quarter is clean.
city in the world" Macao appears as quiet and unexciting as a New
England village on a sunday afternoon.
The reason probably is
all vice is openly conducted thus depriving the casual visitor of
alluring fragmentary glimpses through speak-easy slots.
smoke opium openly and your glance into a building bearing the
Portuguese and frequently English sign "First Class Gambling
very quietly and earnestly while one or two customers are smoking
opium or sleeping on divans around the room edges.
on a windy day and then when he arrives
The forbidden is
ever more enticing.
I left Macao on New Year's Day at 3 A.M. and traveled by
boat to Hongkong four hours away -
then to Canton where I had my first
snake dinner.
Our host hired the best snake cook in Canton and if
you are looking for such a chef I can recommend him highly.
snake wine was not so good.
It tastes like a very inferior grade of
Missouri corn liquor flavored with quinine.
However I drank several
cupfuls and "Boscoed" a couple of snakes with no harmful effects,
except of course to
the snakes.
Am writing this letter on my way from Shanghai to Peiping.
We are flying in one of C. N. A.
C.'s new DC-2's.
My fellow passengers
one German woman - one man who by appearance and gestures
sees too tremen to chinese men and three Japs - the latter com-
plete with maps and note books - somewhat dismayed because we have been
flying "on top" ever since leaving Shanghai and
only now nearing
Tsingtao as we are coming down through the clouds they are all action
climbing around on their sawed-off legs making notes and checking maps
probably
to see if the Chinese like the Americans are
"stupid" enough
to publish accurate ones.
As we go North their swash-buckling will
increase until the
cocky assurance of their swagger makes you
but of course you con-
that impulse
for in North China unfortunately the Rising
the Moon Door in almost total eclipse.
The Chinese individualist smiles benignly and continues his
tolerant placid existence and wonders why everybody gets so hot and
about it all.
Nobody has taken his country away from him.
He still has it and works in the fields where his ancestors have
worked before him,
his descendants will
work after him,
rejoices over
the better state of law and order
and the fact that neither soldiers
nor bandits (to him they are equally to be dreaded) molest him.

sees too tremen to chinese men and three Japs - the latter com-
plete with maps and note books - somewhat dismayed because we have been

only now nearing

probably
to see if the Chinese like the Americans are

As we go North their swash-buckling will
increase until the
cocky assurance of their swagger makes you
but of course you con-
that impulse
for in North China unfortunately the Rising
the Moon Door in almost total eclipse.
The Chinese individualist smiles benignly and continues his
tolerant placid existence and wonders why everybody gets so hot and
about it all.
Nobody has taken his country away from him.
He still has it and works in the fields where his ancestors have
worked before him,
his descendants will
work after him,
rejoices over
the better state of law and order
and the fact that neither soldiers
nor bandits (to him they are equally to be dreaded) molest him.

If the French had been Chinese in 1914 they would probably have accept-
ed without resistance a new
"war lord",
saved millions of
lives,
on working their fields, supported one army instead of two and would
no war debts
to worry about paying or repudiating.
to us who think in terms of Nationalism.
simplicity itself
to the Chinese man who thinks in terms of his own welfare all of
the family weel most of the time, his village some of the time,
his province occasionally and
the Nation not at all.
I did not mean to write an essay on China only you two who
have been here may be interested.
China is scarcely more a part
of China now than is Manchuria
- but on the other hand, from the stand-
point of political economy
it never has been really a part of China
since the revolution.
Actually in the brief period
that I have been
in China the Central Government economically has annexed five provinces
which were formerly a part of China only on the map - namely,
Kiangsi,
no
Szechuen, Kweichow and Yunnan.
Formerly those provinces paid
or attention to the National Government.
Now they do.
airplane is largely responsible.
Szechuen, one of the richest agri-
cultural
above the gorges of the Yangtsze could
A man high up on
sides of
gorges with a handful of rocke could stand off the t. ous
Navy - a punitive expedition against Liu Hsian,
former war lord of the
Province,
would have
bankrupted the National
treasury.
Now a few gallons
of gasoline plus a few bombs and Mr. War Lord reduces his opulent waist
line by a continuing series of kow tows.
Debby reports fron Manila that the big girls, Frances and Bo
are off on a trip
to Saigon and Ankor.
They travel as students with
special
real
parties at a cost unbelievably low.
It is one of the very
compensations of service in the Orient that they have such oppor-
tunities.
They have learned to speak Chinese enough to get along,
through Manchuria,
of Korea, to the bangteze to croneline anaee around the latel
into the Diamond Mountains
up the Yangtsze
to say nothing of seeing
put the first Clipper down
the waters of Manila Bay.
Later they will
"do" South
My work in the Orient is nearing completion and while nothing
has been accomplished of which I am very
proud, nevertheless
the job has
been reasonably well done considering all
the circumstances.
My very
best to you both and
you lina an unbrand one
security and contentment which you so richly deserve.
Very sincerely,
